column3: Please add 'txids' to the lisreceivedbyaddress help text, and can you write up a little test plan for how this should be tested?  (e.g. expected results passing the 'minconf' param, if includeempty=true do you get [] for "txids" (preferred) or is that field just missing, etc).\n

Okay, no problem with help text, but I'm slightly unsure about tests: currently, for example, adding following tests to `rpc_rawparams` routine:

```
    BOOST_CHECK_NO_THROW(r=CallRPC("listreceivedbyaddress"));
    BOOST_CHECK(r.get_array().empty());
```

does not result in failed test, though, of course, it depends on wallet state. 

Should I just add tests for correct handling of param
Still needs a test plan; see https://github.com/bitcoin/QA   for how to write one.\n
Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/1a20469428ef623f4edc2cdac72aef001836536c for binaries and test log.\n

@gavinandresen What is the preferred way to create test protocol for RPC calls? For most users the easiest way, in mu opinion, would be to use Debug window in Bitcoin-Qt. Or is it better to create some script (in e.g. Python) which does all necessary calls via network (purely automatically or may be interactively)?\n

I think it would probably be best to give testers a script to follow.  Install THIS executable, then run it like THIS, then  open the Debug window and execute the following RPC commands: ....

If you write a Python script to try to test this, a bug in THAT code might hide a bug in your code. And testers often notice things that you didn't as they are testing.
This txids will grow indefinitely... not sure it's a good idea.\n

ACK.

@luke-jr They shouldn't, as address reuse is discouraged. If you know you are reusing addresses, you're taking the performance penalty here too.
